structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en: The course is roughly divided into two parts: the first introductory part explains how empirical quantitative social science is to be complemented with quantitatively predictive logical models. The second part covers some of the most commonly used statistical techniques in the social sciences and introduces the students to R.
description.et: Kursus käsitleb kõiki peamisi sotsiaalteaduste metodoloogia osiseid, fookus on kvantitatiivsetel meetoditel ja lähenemistel.

objectives.en: The course offers an introduction into the logic and methods of empirically-oriented quantitative research in the social sciences. It is concerned with how the social scientists use (and should use) logical reasoning and empirical evidence to answer research questions. The course has a dual focus: its first objective is to familiarize the students with the dominant approaches and methods in empirically-oriented social science research. Specifically, it seeks to ensure that MA students are able to read and understand mainstream empirical work in the discipline of political science (i.e. research articles that test hypotheses by statistically analyzing data) and are able to design and implement their own empirical research projects in accordance with the standards of the discipline. The second objective of the course is to complement empirical quantitative inquiry (How things are?), including statistical description, with construction of logical models (How things should be on logical grounds?). These tell us what it is that needs to be measured and analyzed. This part of the course involves thinking logically about the variables and associations that one is focussing on and using visual representations to aid such thinking.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on anda ülevaade erinevatest kvantitatiivsetest meetoditest sotsiaalteadustes ning aidata magistrantidel omandada iseseisva uurimistöö jaoks vajalikud oskused.

notes.et: Martin Mölder is available for meetings (per request). Please address general questions regarding course organization, registration, attendance, etc to him. Questions related to course content and assignments should be addressed to the instructor responsible for the specific section of the course (see schedule).

independent_work.et:
Tasks in data analysis: the students are required to complete independent take-home tasks in statistical analysis, which involve performing tasks and answering a set of questions on a dataset. More detailed instructions will be provided in class. 

Model building exercises, in Taagepera (2015); hand in 5 sets of exercises:
SET 1: Exerc. 2.1; 2.3. 
SET 2: Cases 1 to 5 in Appendix C. 
SET 3: 4.2; 6.3. 
SET 4: Cases 6 to 11 in Appendix C. 
SET 5: 7.1; 7.2; 7.4.

description.et: 5 tasks in data analysis: proper completion of the tasks.
Model building exercises 1 to 5: proper completion of the exercises.
Final exam

grade_preconditions.et: Attendance. All students are required to participate in at least 12 of the 16 sessions (75%) in order to pass the class. If a student has missed more than 4 classes without a valid excuse (for which the instructor has been notified before the class takes place), the grade for the course will be an F regardless of the other tasks that have or have not been completed.

grade_evaluation.et:
- Five tasks in data analysis (a total of 40% of the final grade).
- Five model building exercises solved (a total of 30% of the final grade). NB! All model building exercises should be handed in in class on the day they are due.
- Final exam successfully passed (30% of the final grade).

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.mandatory_materials:
Most of the required readings come from the following sources (see the weekly schedule):

- Rein Taagepera, Logical Models and Basic Numeracy in Social Sciences: 2015. The online text: http://www.psych.ut.ee/stk/Beginners_Logical_Models.pdf

- Andy Field et al, Discovering Statistics Using R. Sage 2012.

description.et: Getting started with R Readings: Field, Ch. 3
Basic concepts in statistics Readings: Field, Ch. 1 & 2
Basic data visualisations Readings: Field, Ch. 4
Measures of central tendency; comparing means Readings: Field, Ch. 9
Correlation Readings: Field, Ch. 6
Regression (OLS) Readings: Field, Ch. 7
Logistic regression Readings: Field, Ch. 8
Categorical data Readings: Field, Ch. 18
Simple logical models and graphing on regular scales. Readings: Taagepera, Ch 1-2 and Appendix C pp. 269-274
Observation, thinking and graphing. Readings: Taagepera, App. C pp. 275-283 and Ch 3 SET 1 DUE: 2.1; 2.3.
Largest component and forbidden regions. Readings: Taagepera, Ch 4-5, and intro to 6 SET 2 DUE: Cases 1 to 5 in Appendix C, pp. 284-289..
Duration of cabinets and graphing on logarithmic scales. Readings: Taagepera, Ch 6-7. SET 3 DUE: 4.2; 6.3..
Thinking inside the box and interlocking relationships. Readings: Taagepera, Ch 8, 9, 10. SET 4 DUE: Cases 6 to 11 in Appendix C, pp. 289-295.
Volatility, and how to test models. Readings: Taagepera, Ch 11-12. SET 5 DUE: 7.1; 7.2; 7.4.
Fermi's piano tuners. Review. Readings: Taagepera, Ch 24.
Exam (with open notes & materials)

audience.et: The course is open only for IRRS, EURUS and DG students
